base_fields = {'confirm_password': <django.forms.fields.CharField object>, 'email': <django.forms.fields.EmailField object>, 'password': <django.forms.fields.CharField object>, 'username': <django.forms.fields.CharField object>}¶
clean()[source]¶

Hook for doing any extra form-wide cleaning after Field.clean() has been called on every field. Any ValidationError raised by this method will not be associated with a particular field; it will have a special-case association with the field named ‘__all__’.

declared_fields = {'confirm_password': <django.forms.fields.CharField object>, 'password': <django.forms.fields.CharField object>}¶
property media¶

apps.users.models module¶

class apps.users.models.AppUser(id, user)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

hashtag_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

id¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>¶
twitterprofile_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

user¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a one-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Restaurant(Model):
    place = OneToOneField(Place, related_name='restaurant')

Restaurant.place is a ForwardOneToOneDescriptor instance.

apps.users.urls module¶

apps.users.views module¶

class apps.users.views.DeleteUserView(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.contrib.auth.mixins.LoginRequiredMixin, django.views.generic.edit.DeleteView

DeleteUserView class extends Django template class DeleteView to use it for deleting users from database. User must be earlier logged in. After deletion app user is redirected to login page. There is also a intermediate html page asking for confirmation of deletion.

model¶

alias of django.contrib.auth.models.User

success_url = '/users/login/'¶
template_name = 'users/user_confirm_delete.html'¶
class apps.users.views.LoginView(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.views.generic.base.View

Class LoginView is used to render login html page and allow app’s users to log in it

form_class¶

alias of apps.users.forms.LoginForm

get(request)[source]¶

GET method renders login page if user is not logged in and index page if he is :param request: GET request :return: login page with appropriate message and form or index page

logger = <Logger apps.users.views (WARNING)>¶
post(request)[source]¶

POST method gets login form and checks for its validity. If it’s valid, it tries to authenticate Django User class instance :param request: POST request :return: index page if user successfully logged in or login page with appropriate message and form otherwise

class apps.users.views.LogoutView(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.contrib.auth.mixins.LoginRequiredMixin, django.views.generic.base.View

Class LogoutView is used to log user out; earlier authentication is of course required

get(request)[source]¶

Method logs user out in the app (if he is earlier logged in) and redirects him to login page :param request: GET request :return: redirect to login page

class apps.users.views.RegisterView(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.views.generic.base.View

Class RegisterView is used to render register html page and add new app’s users

form_class¶

alias of apps.users.forms.UserForm

get(request)[source]¶

GET method renders registration page if user is not logged in and index page if he is :param request: GET request :return: register.html page with appropriate message and form or index page

logger = <Logger apps.users.views (WARNING)>¶
post(request)[source]¶

POST method gets registration form and checks for its validity. If it’s valid, it creates Django User class instance, sets its password, creates companion object AppUser and saves them in database :param request: POST request :return: register.html page with appropriate message and form
